p: We noticed that the predictive value of UGT1A1*28 and *6 polymorphisms on CR after Ara-C based induction therapy is modest in AML patients (CR rate 76.9% in carriers of the UGT1A1*28 and *6 alleles and 63.8% in UGT1A1*1/*1 for both loci), and the association of UGT1A1*28 alone with non-CR risk was nonsignificant after Bonferroni correction for two SNPs (significance set at P < 0.05/2 for 2 SNPs). This may be explained by two reasons: firstly, the lower allele frequency of the UGT1A1*28 polymorphism in our patient cohort. Secondly, the multigenic characteristic of drug response including Ara-C. In our previous studies, we observed that polymorphisms in other genes encoding enzymes in the Ara-C metabolic pathway such as DCK, NME2 (DNPK-B), RRM2, and SAMHD1 are also associated drug response to Ara-C based therapies in AML [ 10, 16]. We suggest that the construction of a decision tree based on multiple genetic variations concomitantly may increase the predictive values of pharmacogenetics biomarkers in AML induction therapy. Of course, the exact usefulness requires to be explored with a large sample size.
